questions.text: Otomycosis is commonly caused by
questions.solution:
Most fungal ear infections are caused by Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus fumigatus, Penicillium and Candida albicans. Otomycosis commonly results from overuse of antibacterial ear drops, which should never be used for more than 7 days.

There are nearly 60 different species of fungi that may be responsible for this infection.

Common fungi include Aspergillus and Candida. Sometimes bacteria can combine with the fungi and make the infection more complicated.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female greenhouse worker seeks medical care for an ulcerative nodule on her right distal forearm that has persisted for over a month. The lesion began as a reddish bump above the right hand where the patient had received multiple scratches from moving thorn-covered bayberry plants. It had been subsequently diagnosed empirically as a staph infection and treated with antibiotics without improvement. At this visit, the patient is afebrile and in no significant pain. Cultures of the lesion yield a thermally dimorphic fungus. A photograph of the fungus grown at ambient temperature is shown. With which organism is the patient infected?
questions.solution: • Sporothrix schenckii. Infection with this organism causes a disease known as cutaneous or lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. It occurs in farm or nursery workers or others handling thorny plants, baled hay, or sphagnum moss. The progression of the lesion occurs slowly with the initial lesion resembling an insect bite and progression to nodules and open ulcers. Diagnosis can be made by finding characteristic fungal forms in cultures from the lesions. The distinctive arrangement of the conidia on the conidiophore and the characteristic thermal dimorphism (i.e., mold at 25°C and yeast at 37°C) are consistent with S. schenckii. The fungus is described as a geophilic species, and traumatic inoculation into the subcutaneous layer is the means by which a person becomes infected. None of the other fungal diseases listed manifest similar symptoms, nor do their fungal etiologies show fungal structures as described in this case. Acremonium spp. are causes of eumycotic mycetoma, a fungal disease found in the tropics. B. dermatitidis is an endemic, dimorphic fungus found in the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys and causes a pulmonary disease that can be accompanied by skin lesions. C. tropicalis is an opportunistic fungus that causes a variety of diseases.

questions.text: A Midwifery was examining a Pregnant Mother in Labour. Suddenly She noticed a Cord lying outside the introitus. Next line of Management is
questions.solution:
• Cord prolapse:
  • Cord lies inside or outside the vagina following rupture of membranes
  • Cord presentation:
  • Cord slips down below the presenting part and is felt lying above the intact bag of membranes
  • Occult prolapse:
  • Cord is placed by the side of the presenting part and is not felt on per vaginal examinaion

 

Management of cord prolapse

  1. Immediate delivery for live baby (Vaginal/forceps/Breech extraction for advanced labour)
  2. Cesarean section within 30 mts for early labour and transverse lie
  3. Vaginal delivery for dead baby provided there are no contraindications for vaginal delivery like transverse lie
  4. Immediately Reposition the cord inside the vagina and not above the presenting part
  5. Minimal handling of cord loops
  6. Presenting part should be elevated eiher manually or by filling the bladder
  7. Put mother in knee chest position or head down tilt preferably in left lateral position.

questions.text: Atopic individuals (i.e., those with a hereditary predisposition to immediate hypersensitivity reactions) produce an increased amount of IgE. Of the following, which one is the most likely explanation for the increased production of IgE?
questions.solution: Atopic disorders, such as hay fever, asthma, eczema, and urticaria, are immediate-hypersensitivity reactions that exhibit a strong familial predisposition and are associated with elevated IgE levels. Several processes seem likely to play a role in atopy, for example, failure of regulation at the T-cell level (e.g., increased production of IL-4 leads to increased IgE synthesis), enhanced uptake and presentation of environmental antigens, and hyperreactivity of target tissues. Target tissues often contain large numbers of Th-2 cells, and these are thought to play a major role in the pathogenesis of atopic reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an objective measure of nasal obstruction.
questions.solution:
• The Cottle's maneuver (CM) is a test in which the cheek on the side to be evaluated is gently pulled laterally with one to two fingers to open the valve. This test is used to determine if the most significant site of nasal obstruction is at the valve or farther inside the nasal cavity.
  • Rhinomanometry is an objective physiologic measure that evaluates transnasal pressure and nasal airflow volume to calculate nasal airway resistance during inspiration.
  • Peak nasal inspiratory flow (PNIF) is an inexpensive, rapid, easy-to-use objective measure that directly measures nasal airflow during maximal inspiration
  • Acoustic rhinometry and rhinomanometry have been used to assess nasal airway patency objectively. We compared nasal obstruction symptoms before and after decongestion with several parameters of these objective tests. The patients assessed their nasal obstruction using a visual analogue scale (VAS).

questions.text: Best treatment of Stage 4 carcinoma larynx is
questions.solution:
Stage III and IV laryngeal cancers

The main options for initial treatment for these cancers are surgery or Immunotherapy might be another option for some people with stage IV cancer. Surgery for these tumors is almost always complete removal of the larynx (total laryngectomy), but a small number of these cancers might be treated by partial laryngectomy chemotherapy with radiation.

Radiation therapy alone (or with the targeted drug cetuximab) may be an option for people who cannot tolerate more intensive treatments

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness in the right lower quadrant. A white blood cell count reveals leucocytosis. Suspecting appendicitis, the child is taken to surgery; however, the removed appendix is grossly and histologically normal. The bacterial cause for the boys symptoms was subsequently identified as a Gram-negative rod after cold enrichment of faecal cultures. What is the aetiology of this infection?
questions.solution: • Yersinia enterocolitica. This Gram-negative rod usually causes a diarrheal illness but can also cause infections that mimic appendicitis.  enterocoliticais part of the normal intestinal flora of cattle and other farm animals. Human infection occurs by ingestion of food or water contaminated with animal feces. The organism is able to grow at refrigerated temperatures while other organisms present in the same faecal sample cannot. This isolation technique is known as cold enrichment. S. typhi and C. jejuni have been isolated from diseased appendices; however, these organisms are isolated at 37 °C. C. difficile is an anaerobic, Gram-positive rod causing antibiotic-associated diarrhoea and pseudomembranous colitis.

questions.text: False about Aluminum phosphide poisoning
questions.solution:
Cyt C oxidase is inhibited instead of Cyt A oxidase.

Aluminum phosphide (Celphos) toxicity occurs due to release of PHOSPHINE on contact with moisture. This phosphine gas inhibits cytochrome C oxidase system of mitochondria or damage by free radicals causes global hypoxia.

Organs with the greatest oxygen requirements appear to be especially sensitive to phosphine, including the brain, kidneys, heart, and liver. Phosphine has a characteristic odor described as 'decaying fish. Cardiac dysrhythmias probably secondary to electrolyte imbalances have been described in sub - lethal acute exposures. Transient atrial fibrillation and sub - endocardial infarction, adrenocortical injury with elevated serum cortisol levels have been reported.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is hospitalized with community-acquired pneumonia. Blood and sputum cultures grew the alpha-haemolytic catalase-negative, bile-soluble, optochin-sensitive organism shown in the photograph. It showed an intermediate degree of resistance to penicillin.What are the other important virulence factors of this organism?
questions.solution: • The organism described in this case is Streptococcuspneumoniae. It is an important cause of community-acquired pneumonia and strains range in sensitivity to penicillin from fully susceptible to intermediately susceptible to highly resistant. Virulent strains of  pneumoniae, also called pneumococcus, produce a thick, polysaccharide capsule that provides protection against complement activation and phagocytosis. Pneumolysin is a unique cytotoxin elaborated by pneumococci. It induces pores in host cell plasma membranes following binding to cholesterol residues, thereby damaging ciliated respiratory epithelial cells and neutrophils. The organism does not elaborate any of the other virulence factors listed. Filamentous hemagglutinin, tracheal cytotoxin, and pertactin are virulence factors of Bordetella pertussis. Neuraminidase and hemagglutinin are envelope glycoproteins of influenza virus. Pyocyanin and endotoxin are two of the multiple virulence factors of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A woman presents with a chronic infection of her foot as seen in the accompanying photograph. Secretion from the lesions, upon Gram staining, clearly reveal the presence of filamentous Gram-positive cells. Which bacterial species is descriptive of the offending agent?
questions.solution: • The actinomycetes, which include  israelii, are a group of organisms characterized as Gram-positive rods commonly found in soil and decaying organic matter or as colonizers of body surfaces. They can infect humans causing cutaneous, pulmonary, or systemic disease. In culture and lesions, these organisms form filamentous or hyphae-like structures. The lesion shown is an actinomycetoma. In general, a mycetoma is described as a chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous tissue involvement. Eumycetoma, although a similar presentation, has a fungal origin. Mycetomas can form as a result of traumatic injury such as walking long distances on a jungle path in flip–flops as may have happened in this case. If treated early with a combination of antibiotics, a full recovery can be expected. None of the other organisms listed are causes of mycetomas.

questions.text: Antigen receptors on T and B cells share which similar feature?
questions.solution: The variable portions of both receptor types are generated by random recombination of genes. Antigen receptors on B and T cells are the product of gene segment rearrangement in order to devise receptors which can recognize various antigens from differing pathogens. Affinity mat- uration (choice A) is the process whereby activated B cells compete for binding with follicular dendritic cells in the germinal centers in order to generate the B cells synthesizing the highest affinity antibodies. T cells require interaction with MHC–peptide complexes in order to undergo activation, whereas B cells can recognize antigens in their natural state (choice B). The constant regions are not identical in nature.

questions.text: A critically ill patient, who has a Foley catheter, develops a serious UTI. The organism is identified as a motile, non urease producing, Gram-negative enteric bacillus with a high degree of antibiotic resistance that rarely causes disease in immune competent people. The agent formed pigments on nutrient agar cultivated at room temperature, as shown in the photograph. What is the etiology of this patient's UTI?
questions.solution: • Serratia marcescens. Serratia is a motile, Gram-negative bacillus of the family Enterobacteriaceae. The species is commonly found in the environment. It can also produce urinary infections in debilitated patients. Unfortunately, this organism has a notorious history of antibiotic resistance, especially to the aminoglycosides and many of the beta-lactam antibiotics. The red pigment or prodigiosin is actually an antibiotic produced by certain strains which gives the microbe a competitive advantage against other nearby environmental bacteria. Prodigiosin is most pronounced in cultures grown at room temperature; only a small percentage of the isolates produce this pigment. None of the other organisms listed fit the description provided in the case.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Leukonychia refers to the white discoloration of nail. It is traditionally classified into three subtypes:

1.True - when pathology originates in matrix and emerges in the nail plate.

2.Apparent - when pathology is in the nail bed.

3.Pseudo - when nail plate pathology is exogenous, for example, onychomycosis

Mees lines: True leukonychia due to arsenic intoxication is characterized by a single or multiple, transverse, narrow whitish line running along the width of the nail and parallel to lunula, and may involve multiple nails. These lines do not disappear on blanching and move distally with time.

Muehrcke's lines: These are apparent leukonychia characterized by double white transverse line , resulting possibly from a localized edematous state in the nail bed exerting pressure on the vascular bed. They are specific for hypoalbuminic state 

Half and half nail or Lindsay nail: Apparent leukonychia with a normal proximal half and abnormal brownish discolored distal half . It is seen in patients of chronic kidney disease with uremic renal failure

Terry nails: Apparent leukonychia with nail that is white proximally and normal distally. It is associated with congestive cardiac failure, adult-onset diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, hemodialysis, and HIV

Yellow nail syndrome

It is characterized by thickening and yellow to yellow-green discoloration of the nails often associated with systemic disease, most commonly lymphedema and compromised respiration due to pleural effusion.

Red lunula

Red lunulae are seen in collagen vascular disease, cardiac failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), cirrhosis, chronic urticaria, psoriasis, and CO poisoning

Periungual telangiectasia is an important clue to systemic involvement in systemic sclerosis, SLE , and dermatomyositis influencing the prognosis of the disease.

questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma most commonly appears as a pearly white, dome-shaped papule with prominent telangiectatic surface vessels. The margins are characteristically rolled up.
  • A biopsy should be performed in all patients with suspected BCC to confirm the diagnosis and determine the histologic subtype. 
  • Therapy selection depends on the patient's age and gender as well as the site, size, and type of lesion. No single treatment method is ideal for all lesions or all patients
  • Treatment of BCC is usually surgical, but some forms of BCC are amenable to medical treatment or radiation therapy. The various types of therapy include Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS), standard surgical excision, EDC, radiation, photodynamic therapy, cryosurgery, topical therapies, and systemic medications such as Vismodegib.
  • Mohs surgery provides the best long-term cure rate of any treatment modality for BCC. MMS is the gold standard for treating high-risk BCCs and recurrent BCCs
  • Topical 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and Imiquimod 5% cream are approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat superficial BCC
  • A more recent treatment for patients with advanced or metastatic BCC that is untreatable with conventional therapeutic methods is Hedgehog pathway inhibitors. The FDA approved Vismodegib in 2012. A second inhibitor, sonidegib, was also approved
  • Radiation therapy is a primary option for treating BCC or SCC if surgery is contraindicated.

Frank sign refers to the presence of a diagonal crease in the earlobe that runs backwards from the tragus at a 45 degree angle across the lobule to the rear edge of the auricle.

CLINICAL RELEVANCE- It may be a predictor of coronary artery disease and/or diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Best marker for dyslipidemia
questions.solution:
• The current National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines recommend specific target levels of LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) and HDL cholesterol (HDL-C) for determining cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and evaluating the effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapies.
  • While there is a growing consensus that levels of apolipoprotein (apo) B and the ratio of apo B/apo A-I are more accurate predictors of CVD risk, the question has been raised as to whether it is realistic to expect patients and health professionals to switch from cholesterol-based guidelines to apolipoprotein-based guidelines.
  • Because it will take time before apolipoprotein terminology is recognized by the general public and recommended by the NCEP Adult Treatment panel to evaluate risk, it may be more efficacious to continue adhering to the already familiar and proven measurements of the LDL-C/HDL-C ratio.
  • The following review provides evidence that the LDL-C/HDL-C ratio continues to be a valuable and standard tool to evaluate CVD risk in all populations.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient is being treated in the medical ICU for pneumonia. Since the culture yielded MRSA sensitive to Vancomycin, was started on the drug. Soon after drug administration he developed flushing, tachycardia and hypotension. What is the likely phenomenon that has occurred?
questions.solution: Rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin can cause erythematous and urticarial reactions, flushing, tachycardia and hypotension. The extreme flushing that can occur is called redman syndrome. This is not an allergic reaction, but a direct toxic effect of vancomycin on mast cells, causing them to release histamine. It can be prevented by prolonging the infusion period to 1-2 hours or pre-treatment with an antihistamine like diphenhydramine.

questions.text: A 7 month old child was having vomitings upon having fruit juice feeds, but is of normal weight. What enzyme defect could be the cause for fructose intolerance?
questions.solution:
'Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is an inborn error of fructose metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive condition. Individuals affected with HFI are asymptomatic until they ingest fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol. If fructose is ingested, the enzymatic block at aldolase B causes an accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This accumulation has downstream effects on gluconeogenesis and regeneration of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Symptoms of HFI include vomiting, hypoglycemia, jaundice, hemorrhage, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia and potentially kidney failure'.

Hence, typically, a patient of hereditary fructose intolerance remains asymptomatic till the time of 'weaning'. It is a much

Regarding other options –

  • Essential fructosuria - Essential fructosuria caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase is a clinically benign condition characterized by the incomplete metabolism of fructose in the liver, leading to its excretion in urine. Fructokinase(sometimes called ketohexokinase) is the first enzyme involved in the degradation of fructose to fructose - 1 - phosphate in the liver. This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms.
  • Fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase deficiency - presents in first 4 days of life with severe hyperventilation, profound lactic acidosis and hypoglycemia. Later on, episodes of irritability, somnolescence and coma, apneic spells, dyspnea and tachycardia and muscular hypotonia develop. The patient has such episodes after ingestion of large amount of fructose, especially after periods of fasting. Such episodes decrease with age and patient generally have normal somatic and psychomotor development. Hence failure to thrive is less common as compare to HFI. But overall, the incidence of Fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase deficiency is less as compared to HFI.

The above mentioned points, added to the fact that the given questions gives a classical setting of 'weaning' and age as 7 months points towards HFI being a better answer here.

questions.text: Most common congenital heart valve defect is?
questions.solution:
BICUSPID AORTIC VALVE DISEASE

  • Most common congenital heart valve defect.
  • Males are more commonly affected.
  • Pattern of inheritance is Autosomal dominant.
  • Gene mutations implicated are: NOTCH1, Endothelial nitric oxide synthase
  • Most common cause of isolated aortic stenosis in adults
  • Higher incidence of ascending aortic aneurysm
  • Higher incidence of aortic dissection

questions.text: A 35-year old -2D myopic male with a family history of glaucoma came to the eye OPD for a routine refraction follow-up. On examination, his IOP was 25mm Hg and 21 mm Hg in the right and left eyes respectively; pachymetry readings were 550 microns and 580 microns respectively. The fundus images of both eyes are as shown. The visual fields were normal. Which of the following statement is true about this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of OCULAR HYPERTENSION

  • Ocular hypertension has been defined by:
    • Corrected intraocular pressure (IOP) higher than 21 mm Hg
    • Normal optic nerve and
    • Normal visual field
  • Optic discs shown in the images are normal.
  • AN IOP of 26 mm Hg or more confers a higher risk of progression to POAG and may warrant initiation of treatment, in the presence of other risk factors. For an IOP of 25 mm Hg, anti-glaucoma drugs need not be started.
  • The 5-factor model for predicting progression of OHT to POAG:
  1. Higher Age
  2. Increased IOP(26mmHg or more)
  3. Pachymetry <555 microns (question says 550 microns in the right eye)
  4. Larger CDR
  5. Increased PSD(Pattern Standard Deviation) on visual fields
  • Family history is an independent risk factor for development of POAG. It is not a risk factor for OHT progressing into POAG

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension(IIH) except:
questions.solution:
Obesity is a risk-factor for IIH. BMI of 38 falls under Class 2 Obesity.

  • BMI less than 18.5 : Underweight
  • BMI  18.5 to <25: Normal
  • BMI 25.0 to <30: Overweight
  • BMI 30.0 or higher: Obesity

Obesity is subdivided into categories:

  • Class 1: BMI of 30 to < 35
  • Class 2: BMI of 35 to < 40
  • Class 3: BMI of 40 or higher. Class 3 obesity is sometimes categorized as 'extreme' or 'severe' obesity

Vitamin A intoxication is a risk factor for IIH; not deficiency

questions.text: Lesion of which of the following structures produces a homonymous pie in the sky visual field defect?
questions.solution:
a – Chiasma (Lesion produces heteronymous visual field defect)

b – Optic tract (Lesion produces contralateral homonymous hemianopia)

c – Lateral Geniculate body (lesion produces contralateral homonymous sectoranopia or sector-sparing hemianopia)

d – Meyer’s loop ( Inferior fibres of optic radiation passing through temporal lobe; Lesion produces contralateral homonymous pie in the sky visual field defect, i.e. contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia)

questions.solution:
In a case of subclinical hypothyroidism, the following are the indications for treatment :

  2. TSH value more than 10 mIU/L
  3. Symptoms of hypothyroidism

questions.text: The tonometer shown in the image is:
Speckled appearance of myocardium in Echo is a feature of ?
questions.solution: 'Speckled appearance' of myocardium in ECHO is a feature of cardiac amyloidosis. This is due to amyloid accumulation in the cardiac tissue.

questions.text: The corneal topography of a 20-year old female patient with complaints of blurred vision is shown here. She has been using both glasses and contact lens. She had her last change of glasses 7 months ago and is now also complaining of contact lens intolerance. What is the treatment of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of corneal topography showing  the curvature map. The curvature map shows inferior steepening (warmer colors – orange and red) where the maximum curvature is 64.3D – advanced keratoconus. That she is intolerant of her contact lens is also explained by this high K value.

The progressive nature of keratoconus has resulted in blurred vision despite the BCVA obtained by refraction testing, done 7 months ago. C3R – Corneal collagen crosslinking using riboflavin(photosensitizer) and UV-A light is the treatment of choice to arrest the progression of keratoconus.

ICL(implantable collamer lens) is a good option for axial myopia, especial unilateral cases of high axial myopia.

ICRS(IntraCorneal Ring Segments) – act as a temporising measure in the management of keratoconus. Moreover, the corneal thickness should be adequate to implant ICRS.

DSEK – Descemet Stripping Endothelial Keratoplasty is not helpful in keratoconus as the abnormality in KC is in the stromal collagen. The endothelium, per se, and the Descemet’s membrane are healthy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of high fever and malaise for the last 4 days His parents say that he began limping yesterday and seems to refrain from using his right leg He has no recent history of travel or exposure to a person with similar symptoms His temperature is 39.4 C (103 F) Passive range of motion does not elicit pain and no joint effusion is seen. However, the boy refuses to bear weight with his right lower extremity. Scintigraphy is most likely to reveal increased focal radiotracer uptake in which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of Hematogenous osteomyelitis
  • Hematogenous osteomyelitis predominantly affects children particularly boys It usually affects the metaphysis of long bones, as this region contains slow-flowing, sinusoidal vasculature that is conducive to microbial passage Adults are less likely to develop hematogenous osteomyelitis in the long bones due to changes associated with epiphysial closure.
  • Hematogenous osteomyelitis begins with a seeding event that causes an acute cellulitis of the bone marrow. The resulting inflammation within the confined bony space leads to increased intramedullary pressure, which compromises blood flow and forces infectious exudate through vascular channels into the cortex and periosteal region. Disruption of the periosteal blood supply further contributes to bone ischemia, leading to necrosis. Without treatment, the infection can progress to chronic suppurative osteomyelitis, a condition in which necrotic bone (ie. sequestrum) serves as a reservoir for infection and becomes covered by a poorly constructed shell of new bone called an involucrum. One or more sinus tracts develop to drain the purulent material into the soft tissue or out to the skin surface. Proper treatment includes antibiotic therapy and debridement of necrotic bone
  • Examples of flat bones are the skull, sternum and bones of the pelvis. Osteomyelitis affecting the skull most commonly occurs via contiguous spread of infection from mastoiditis or dental abscess
  • Ewing sarcoma typically arises in diaphysis of the long bones, especially the femur. It is the second most common malignant bone tumor in children after osteosarcoma However, it occurs more frequently in older children (ages 10-15 years). Additionally, this patient's acute symptom onset and high-grade fever are more typical of an infectious process.
  • The long bone epiphysis is usually spared in osteomyelitis unless the acute infection is not treated. The infection could then spread into the epiphysis and adjacent joint resulting in a pyogenic (septic) arthritis

questions.text: A 29 year old male athlete suddenly collapsed and died during a football game. At autopsy the following finding was seen on gross examination. He had a history of two similar deaths in the family previously. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
This is a classical scenario of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy where sudden death can occur in young, otherwise normal athlete / adult. Family history of similar deaths further vindicates the diagnosis.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

  • Autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in one of the several genes encoding sarcomeric proteins (beta-myosin heavy chain, troponin T, Myosin binding protein C)
  • Characteristic feature:
  • Dynamic LV outflow obstruction and impaired diastolic filling due to:

- Myocardial hypertrophy without ventricular dilation

- Assymetric septal hypertrophy

- Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve

  • Systolic function preserved with normal Ejection fraction and cardiac output
  • Clinical features:
    • Dyspnea in the MC complaint
    • Prominent ‘a’ wave in JVP
    • Jerky pulse
    • Double of triple apical impulse
    • Systolic ejection murmur (diamond shaped)- does not radiate to carotid artery
    • Sudden death may be the first manifestation
  • Pathological features
    • Disproportionate thickening of ventricular septum compared to free wall (1:3)
    • Banana like ventricular cavity
    • Extensive myofiber hypertrophy
    • Myofibre disarray
  • Risk factors of sudden death in HCM
    • History of cardiac arrest or sustained VT
    • Non sustained VT or ambulatory ECG monitoring
    • Recurrent syncope
    • Family history of sudden death
    • LV thickness > 30 mm
    • Abnormal BP response to exercise
  • Management
    • Beta blockers and L-type calcium channel blockers (Verapamil) are the first line treatment
    • In case of refractory symptoms and risk of arrhythmias, Disopyramide to be added (Amiodarone can also be used)
    • In medically refractory cases, alcohol septal ablation / mitral surgery to be done
    • ICD insertion to be done in patients with high risk of sudden cardiac death
    • Drugs contraindicated: Digoxin, Frusemide, Arteriorlar dilators

questions.text: A 24-year-old African American woman comes to the hospital reporting left hip and pelvic pain. She has a constant dull ache at rest that is exacerbated by movement of the hip or weight bearing. Her medical history is significant for sickle cell disease, pneumococcal pneumonia and acute chest syndrome. Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 15 min. The patient appears calm but mildly uncomfortable CVS an RS examination is normal. Pedal pulses are full, and there is normal capillary refill and sensation in the feet. No redness or warmth is present over the hip joint, but she has decreased passive rotation, extension, and abduction at the hip. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pain?
questions.solution:
• This patient with hip pain decreased range of motion and underlying sickle cell disease, has osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) of the femoral head Osteonecrosis occurs due to impaired blood supply to a segment of bone. The femoral head is the most common location.
  • Conditions associated with osteonecrosis include the following:
  1. Sickle cell disease leads to thrombotic occlusion of arteries.
  2. Embolic occlusion (fat emboli, decompression sickness) can also cause osteonecrosis
  3. Injury to the vessel wall (vasculitis) causes impaired blood supply (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus)
  4. High-dose corticosteroid therapy and alcoholism are also associated with osteonecrosis of the femoral head, although the mechanism is unknown
  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head presents with chronic progressive groin and hip pain that is exacerbated by weight-bearing. Physical examination reveals restricted movement in the affected joint, with no swelling, erythema, or warmth in the surrounding area. Microscopic analysis of the wedge-shaped zone of affected bone is notable for dead bony trabeculae (empty lacunae) and fat necrosis.
  • Trochanteric bursitis causes sharp, intermittent pain at the lateral hip and thigh. Pain is increased with pressure on the affected hip (eg, lying on the side) and with walking Restricted joint movement is not usually found.
  • Osteoarthritis tends to occur in older patients and is not associated with sickle cell disease. Osteoarthritis causes pain during activity that is relieved by rest. Joint instability and crepitus may be present.
  • Septic arthritis manifests with acute onset of pain in the joint. Physical examination shows swelling, erythema, and warmth

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, cavitatory lung nodules and renal failure. What will be the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Clues for diagnosis of Vasculitic disorders

  • lderly patient, headache in temporal region, symmetrical pain and stiffness in shoulder/hip , with jaw claudication and blindness / diplopia
    • Giant cell arteritis / Temporal arteritis (Rx: Systemic corticosteroids)
  • Young female, ocular disturbances, arm claudication / Raynaud’s phenomenon, weakened pulses of upper extremity
    • Takayasu arteritis
  • Renovascular hypertension, digital gangrene, mononeuritis multiplex, association with Hepatitis B / Hairy cell leukemia, absence of glomerulonephritis, sparing of pulmonary artery
    • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Allergic rhinitis, asthmatic attacks with infiltrates and eosinophilia, mononeuritis multiplex
    • Churg Strauss syndrome (Rx: Cyclophosphamide)
  • Chronic sinusitis, nasal septal perforation, nasopharyngeal ulceration, persistent pneumonitis with cavitation of lung, focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis
    • Wegener’s granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangitis)
  • Children < 5 years, desquamative rash, erythema of hands and feet with peeling, non purulent conjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, coronary artery aneurysms
    • Kawasaki’s disease (Rx: IV immunoglobulin)
  • Palpable purpura, peripheral neuropathy, Arthalgia-myalgia, glomerulonephritis, association with Hepatitis C
    • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
  • Children 4-8 years, palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthalgia, glomerulonephritis
    • Henoch Schonlein purpura
  • Recurrent oro-genital ulceration, recurrent hypopyon / iritis / posterior uveitis, positive pathergy test, HLA B51 association
    • Behcet’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this 65-year old female patient's findings?
questions.solution:
Patients with osteoarthritis(OA) of the hands may also have osteophyte formation leading to bony enlargement of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints (Heberden and Bouchard nodes respectively).

OA also commonly involves the spine and the large weight-bearing joints of the lower extremities (knees, hips) Morning stiffness is more typical of the inflammatory arthritides such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA) but may be experienced for a short duration (<30 minutes) in patients with OA as well

In contrast, morning stiffness in RA may persist for hours and is often accompanied by systemic symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss). RA typically causes symmetric arthritis of the metacarpophalangeal, PIP, and other joints, but DIP joint involvement is less common. In contrast to the bony enlargement in OA, the involved joints in RA have active synovitis with warmth and spongy swelling.



CMC = carpometacarpal; DIP = distal interphalangeal; MCP = metacarpophalangeal

Serology profile done for a patient is mentioned below. What is the likely cause of the abnormal findings.

HBsAg : negative
HBV DNA : negative
HBeAg : negative
Anti HBcAg: positive
questions.solution:
Precore-mutant: variety of Hepatitis B virus that does not produce Hepatitis B virus e antigen (HbeAg). Infections produced by mutants are difficult to treat and cause disease long duration with increased risk of transformation to cirrhosis and malignancy

questions.text: An 8 year old boy with distal femur epiphyseal lesion. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chondroblastoma is a benign, cartilage-producing neoplasm usually arising in the epiphyses of skeletally immature patients

- Most patients are between 10 and 25 years of age at diagnosis and there is a male predominance.

- Patients with skull and temporal bone involvement tend to present at an older age (40-50 years).

Sites of involvement:

- Usually arises in the epiphyses of the distal and proximal femur, followed by the proximal tibia and proximal humerus.

- Patients with tumors arising in the flat bones, vertebrae and short tubular bones tend to be older and skeletally mature.

Clinical findings:

- Majority of patients complain of localized mild pain

- Soft tissue swelling, joint stiffness and limitation, and limp are reported less commonly.

- Minority of patients may develop joint effusion, especially around the knee.

Imaging:

- Typically lytic, centrally or eccentrically placed, relatively small lesions (3 to 6 cm), occupying less than one half of the epiphysis.

- Sharply demarcated, with or without  a thin sclerotic border.

- The presence of sclerotic rim, along with the younger age of the patient, helps to differentiate chondroblastoma from giant cell tumor of bone, which generally lacks sclerotic border and occurs in patients less than 20 years.

Histopathology:

- Densely cellular composed of an admixture of mononuclear chondroblasts and multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells.

- Chondroblasts grow in sheets, have eosinophilic cytoplasm, well defined cell borders, and eccentrically placed reniform or coffe-bean shaped nuclei.

- Matrix generally consist of poorly formed matrix cartilage, Which mineralization may form 'chicken-wire' pattern around single cells.

- Mitotic activity and necrosis are common

- Osteoclast-type giant cells are scattered throughout the tumor but are most numerous in areas of matrix production and hemorrhage.

Immunohistochemistry:

- Chondroblasts express S-100 and vimentin but may also stain for keratin and epithelial membrane antigen.

Genetics:

- Structural anomalies involving chromosomes 5 and 8.

Prognosis:

- 80-90% of chondroblastomas are successfully treated by simple curettage with bone grafting.

- Local recurrence rates range between 14-18% and occur usually within two years.

questions.text: A 23 year old male patient presented with a history of back pain, which is more in the morning and relieved by exercise and bathing in warm water. What is the finding likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Presence of low back pain and morning stiffness that radiates to buttocks and thighs and improvement of symptoms with activity is a cardinal feature of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Upper lobe fibrosis of lung may occur as an extra-articular manisfestation of AS which can result in decreased chest wall expansion
  • Conjunctivitis and urethritis associated with arthritis is a feature of Reiter’s syndrome. Large joints are involved commonly and lesions like keratoderma blenorrhagica can be associated
  • Pleural nodules with arthritis is seen in Rheumatoid arthritis. Morning stiffness is present with characteristic symmetrical involvement of small joints of hand and sparing of DIP. Spine involvement is limited to cervical region
  • Distal phalangeal involvement with arthritis is seen in Osteoarthritis and Psoriatic arthritis. Involvement of large weight bearing joints like hip or knee in middle age – post menopausal women is suggestive of Osteoarthritis while presence of violaceous, scaly plaques in skin in a patient with arthritis could suggest Psoriasis.

Extra-articular manifestations of Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Prostatitis (most common) – usually asymptomatic
  • Anterior uveitis in 1/4th of patients
  • AV conduction defects and Aortic regurgitation
  • Amyloidosis
  • Upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • AS is also known as Bechtrew’s / Marie-Strumpell disease
  • HLA B-27 present in 90% patients
  • Bilateral symmetrical sacroileitis is the characteristic feature
  • Schober test is used to assess the mobility of lumbosacral spine
  • Radiological features: b/l sacroileitis with shiny corner sign and characteristic squaring of verterbra; Bamboo spine is a late finding
  • Increased fecal carriage of Klebsiella aerogenes occur in AS patients

choices.text: Urine protein levels range from 20 mg to 200 mg /day
It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetics
Not detected by routine dipstick method

questions.text: All of these are true about microalbuminuria except:
questions.solution:
Microalbuminuria

  • Abnormally high permeability for albumin in glomerulus
  • The term ‘microalbuminuria’ is being replaced by ‘moderately increased albuminuria’
  • Diagnosis:
    • 24 hour urine albumin testing yields a value between 30 – 299 mg
    • Albumin / Creatinine ratio (ACR) giving a value of 30–300 µg albumin /mg creatinine (30-300 mg/g)
    • Dipstick proteinuria may yield absent / trace values for albumin
  • Clinical significance
    • Marker of vascular endothelial dysfunction
    • Earliest biochemical marker for Diabetic nephropathy
    • Independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetics
    • Important prognostic marker for kidney disease
      • in diabetes mellitus
      • in hypertension
      • in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
    • Risk factor for venous thromboembolism
    • Increasing microalbuminuria during the first 48 hours after admission to ICU predicts increased risk for acute respiratory failure, multi-organ failure and overall mortality

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suffers an infarction of the anterior left ventricular wall. He receives therapy with anti-arrhythmic and pressor agents. He is in stable condition until he develops severe breathlessness 3 days later. An echocardiogram shows a markedly decreased ejection fraction. Representative chest radiographic findings are shown in the figure above. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present in his lungs?
questions.solution: Acute left ventricular failure after a myocardial infarction causes venous congestion in the pulmonary capillary bed and increased hydrostatic pressure, which leads to pulmonary edema by transudation in the alveolar space. Neutrophils and fibrin would be found in cases of acute inflammation of the lung (i.e., pneumonia). Fibrosis and hemosiderin-filled macrophages (heart failure cells) would be found in long-standing, not acute, left ventricular failure. Purulent exudate in the pleural space (empyema) or draining from bronchi results from bacterial infection, not heart failure. No pleural effusions are present in this radiograph. Fluid collections are likely to be transudates (few cells and minimal protein) in noninflammatory conditions.

questions.text: A patient presented with a steering wheel injury to the right side of chest with breathlessness and shock. How will you differentiate between tension pneumothorax and cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
• Sudden onset breathlessness and shock following blunt trauma to chest can be due to Tension pneumothorax, Cardiac tamponade or less commonly Aortic dissection rupturing into pleura / bronchus
  • Due to positive intrathoracic pressure in Tension pneumothorax and decreased diastolic filling in cardiac tamponade due to rapid accumulation of blood in pericardial space, there is peripheral pooling of blood resulting in raised JVP and decreased cardiac output indicated by weak pulse and narrow pulse pressure
  • Accumulation of large volumes of air in pleural cavity in Tension pneumothorax and massive collection of blood in pericardial cavity in cardiac tamponade cause muffling of heart sounds
  • Tension pneumothorax cause absent breath sounds while it is normally heard in cardiac tamponade

Tension Pneumothorax

  • Occurs during chest trauma, mechanical ventilation and resuscitation efforts
  • Small one way communication between airway and pleura causing large volume of air getting trapped in pleura and intra pleural pressure rise well above atmospheric pressure
  • Examination reveals:
    • Cyanosis
    • Hypotension, tachycardia
    • Pulsus paradoxus
    • Jugular venous distension
    • Unilateral chest expansion with shift of trachea and mediastinum to contralateral side
    • Diminished breath sounds
    • Hyper-resonance to percussion
  • Management
    • A large bore needle is inserted into the pleural space through 2nd anterior intercostal space
    • Needle should be left in place until a thoracostomy tube can be inserted
    • Video Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery often required if the communication doesn’t close spontaneously

Cardiac tamponade

  • The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade
  • The quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 mL when the fluid develops rapidly to as much as >2000 mL in slowly developing effusions
  • In constrictive pericarditis, ventricular filling is unimpeded during early diastole while in tamponade, ventricular filling is impeded throughout diastole
  • Beck’s triad:
    • Hypotension
    • Absent heart sounds
    • Jugular venous distension with prominent x descent and absent y descent
  • Features:
    • Kussmaul sign and pericardial knock absent (present in constrictive pericarditis)
    • Electrical alternans present
    • Pulsus paradoxus common
    • ECHO reveals pericardial effusion and diastolic RA and RV collapse with normal myocardial thickness

questions.text: In an experiment, thrombus formation is studied in areas of vascular damage. The propagation of a thrombus in an area of vascular injury to adjacent normal arteries is prevented. Which of the following substances diminishes thrombus propagation by activating protein C?
questions.solution: • Thrombomodulin is present on intact endothelium and binds thrombin, which then inhibits coagulation by activating protein C. Normally, thrombin activates factors V, VIII, and IX, and also stabilizes the secondary hemostatic plug by activating factor XIII, which cross-links fibrin. Thrombin helps activate platelets. Fibrin protein forms a meshwork that is essential to thrombus formation.

questions.text: A 9 year old boy presented with difficulty in climbing stairs and combing hair. On examination, rash present on the knuckles of hand and below the lower eyelids. What is the next diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
Proximal muscle weakness in the presence of characteristic skin lesions as described makes the diagnosis of Dermatomyositis most likely.

Dermatomyositis

  • Usually associated with polymyositis as a symptom complex.
  • Bilateral proximal muscle weakness occur in conjunction with or following appearance of skin lesions
  • Cutaneous manifestations:
    • Heliotrope rash: purplish discolouration of upper eyelid ( MC manifestation)
    • Gottron’s papules: violaceous flat topped papules particularly over MCP, PIP joints
    • Shawl sign: poikiloderma over ‘V’ of the neck or upper back
    • Dowling’s lines: linear erythrosquamous lines over the metacarpals
    • Mechanic’s hands: hyperkeratosis along radial and palmar aspects of hand
  • Associations
    • Internal malignancy in 25% (MC: ca ovary, ca lung)
    • Inflammatory arthritis (anti Jo-1 antibody positivity)
    • Interstitial lung disease
  • Diagnosis
    • Elevated Creatine kinase is the most sensitive investigation (CK-MM)
    • Anti Mi-2 antibody in amyopathic variant; anti 155/140 in malignancy associated
    • Gold standard: Muscle biopsy: perifascicular atrophy
  • Treatment
    • Corticosteroids, Immunosuppressives
    • Methotrexate
    • Hydroxychloroquine

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has had altered consciousness and slurred speech for the past 24 hours. A head CT scan shows a right temporal hemorrhagic infarction. Cerebral angiography shows a distal right middle cerebral arterial occlusion. Within the past 3 years, she has had an episode of pulmonary embolism. A pregnancy 18 months ago ended in miscarriage. Laboratory studies show a false-positive serologic test for syphilis,normal prothrombin time (PT), elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and normal platelet count. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution: These findings are characteristic of a hypercoagulable state. The patient has antibodies that react with cardiolipin, a phospholipid antigen used for the serologic diagnosis of syphilis. These so-called antiphospholipid antibodies are directed against phospholipid-protein complexes such as β2-glycoprotein I and thrombin and are sometimes called lupus anticoagulant because they are present in some patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or other autoimmune states. Patients with antiphospholipid syndrome have recurrent arterial and venous thrombosis and repeated miscarriages. In vitro, these antibodies inhibit coagulation by interfering with the assembly of phospholipid complexes, and a “mixing study” with normal serum will not correct the PTT (which primarily measures factors II, V, VIII, IX, X, XI, and XII and fibrinogen in the “intrinsic pathway” of in vitro coagulation). In vivo, the antibodies induce a hypercoagulable state by unknown mechanisms. Disseminated intravascular coagulation is an acute consumptive coagulopathy characterized by elevated PT and PTT, and decreased platelet count. The PT and PTT are normal in patients with factor V (Leiden) mutation. Hypercholesterolemia promotes atherosclerosis over many years, and the risk of arterial thrombosis increases

questions.text: A patient is sent for PAC before his scheduled surgery. On seeing the CT- Abdomen of this patient, the anesthetist makes a mental list of the drugs to be avoided intra-operatively. Which of the following drugs is likely to be on this list?
questions.solution:
• The CT image shows suprarenal mass arising from adrenal gland, probably a pheochromocytoma
  • PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA - Catecholamine-secreting tumors of chromaffin tissue.
    • Usually located in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic paraganglia, but may be found anywhere chromaffin tissue exists.
    • 90% are found in the adrenal medulla.
    • The catecholamines are epinephrine, norepinephrine and dopamine. These three compounds are found in the chromaffin cells of the sympathetic nervous system, which includes the adrenal medulla, aberrant tissue along the sympathetic chain and paraganglia.
    • Approximately 5% of cases of pheochromocytomas are inherited as an autosomal dominant trait either alone or as part of the neoplastic syndrome, multiple endocrine adenomatosis:
      • Type IIa (Sipple syndrome)
      • Type IIb
      • Von Hippel – Lindau syndrome
      • Neurofibromatosis
  • Drugs to be avoided in Pheochromocytoma:
    • Atropine
    • Pancuronium
    • Ketamine
    • Morphine
    • Atracurium
    • Pancuronium
    • Halothane
  • Drugs used to control Hypertension in pheochromocytoma:

    • Diltiazem

    • Propranolol

questions.text: Increased intracranial tension is related to?
questions.solution:
Cushing’s reflex

Increased intracranial tension -> compression of intracranial blood vessels -> vasomotor centre ischemia -> Activation of vasomotor centre -> Increased sympathetic discharge -> Hypertension and tachycardia -> Increased Mean Arterial pressure stimulating arterial baroreceptors -> Bradycardia with persistence of hypertension (due to vasomotor centre ischemia)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common initial manifestation of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
MALIGNANT HYPERTHERMIA (MH)

  • Rare genetic disorder characterized by an acute hypermetabolic state within muscle tissue following induction of general anesthesia
  • Risk Factors:
  1. Drugs:
    • Halogenated general anesthetics:
      • Cyclopropane
      • Halothane
      • Isoflurane
      • Sevoflurane
      • Desflurane
      • Enflurane
      • Methoxyflurane
    • Nondepolarizing muscle relaxants - Succinylcholine
  1. Family history of Malignant hyperthermia
  2. Myopathy
  • Pathology:

Abnormalities in:

  • Ryanodine Ryr1 receptor - This is a calcium channel receptor responsible for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and plays a critical role in muscle depolarization
  • Secondary messengers and modulators of calcium release, such as fatty acids and phosphatidylinositol may have a role
  • Sodium channel in skeletal muscle may also play a role
  • Sign and symptoms:
  1. Hypermetabolism
    • ET CO2, production
    • Increase O2 consumption
    • Decreases mixed venous O2 tension
    • Cyanosis
    • Mottling
  1. Increased sympathetic activity
    • Tachycardia
    • Hypertension
    • Arrhythmia
  1. Muscle damage
    • Masseter spasm
    • Generalized rigidity
    • ↑ Serum creatinine kinase
    • ↑K
    • ↑Na
    • ↑PO4
    • Myoglobinuria
  1. Hyperthermia
    • Fever
    • Shivering
  • Treatment-Malignant Hyperthermia Protocol
    • Discontinue volatile anesthetic and succinylcholine
    • Hyperventilate with 100% O2, at high flow
    • Administer IV sodium bicarbonate, 1-2 mg/kg
    • Mix dantrolene sodium with sterile distilled water and administer 2.5 mg/kg IV as soon as possible
    • Institute cooling measures (lavage, cooling blanket, cold intravenous solutions)
    • Administer inotropes and antiarrhythmic agents as necessary
    • Administer additional doses of dantrolene, if needed
    • Change anesthetic tubing and soda lime
    • Monitor urinary output, K+, Ca2+, blood gases, end-tidal carbon dioxide; perform clotting studies. Treat severe hyperkalemia with dextrose, 25-50 g intravenously, and regular insulin, 10-20 U intravenously
    • Consider invasive monitoring of arterial blood pressure and central venous pressure

questions.text: The part of PCT which is most susceptible for ischemic injury is?
questions.solution:
• Regions of the kidney most prone to ischemic injury are the S3 segment of the proximal tubule and the medullary thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (mTAL), as these tubular areas exist physiologically in relatively lower oxygen conditions.
  • The S3 segment, in particular, has a much lower capability of producing energy through glycolysis under anaerobic conditions than the mTAL.

questions.text: In spinal anesthesia, drug is injected between:
questions.solution:
SPINAL ANESTHESIA

  • Cerebrospinal fluid is found in the space between the pia and arachnoid (subarachnoid space).


The spinal approach to the intrathecal space is midline with a straight line shot. After infiltration with lidocaine, the spinal needle is introduced into the skin, angled slightly cephalad. The needle traverses the skin, followed by the subcutaneous fat. As the needle courses deeper, it will engage the supraspinous ligament and then the interspinous ligament; the practitioner will note this as an increase in tissue resistance. Next later will be the ligamentum flavum, and this would present like a 'pop.' On popping through this ligament, is the approach to the epidural space, which is the point of placement for epidurally - administered medications and catheters. This also presents the point where the loss of resistance is felt to the injection of saline or air. For spinal anesthesia , the clinician proceeds with needle insertion until penetration of the dura-subarachnoid membranes, which is signalled by free - flowing CSF. It is at this point that the administration of spinal medication takes place.

EPIDURAL ANESTHESIA

  • The epidural space is a potential space.
  • It contains connective tissue, venous plexuses and adipose tissue.
  • It is found between the connective tissue covering the vertebrae and the ligamentum flavumposteriorly and the dura mater anteriorly
  • Laterally it is bound by the pedicles and the intervertebral foramina.
  • It extends from the foramen magnum, where the dura is fused to the base of the skull, to the sacral hiatus.
  • The plica mediana dorsalis is a connective tissue band that may extend from the dura mater to the ligamentum flavum, which divides the posterior epidural space into right and left compartments. Clinically, this is significant because it may affect the spread of epidurally injected medications

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used most commonly to assess the depth of anesthesia:
questions.solution:
Monitoring the depth of anaesthesia should prevent intraoperative awareness and help to ensure that an exact dose of anaesthetic drugs is given to minimize adverse cardiovascular effects caused by overly large doses

Methods to monitor the depth of anesthesia:

  • Monitoring of depth of anesthesia is assessed mainly clinically:
  1. Tachycardia
  2. Hypertension
  3. Lacrimation
  4. Perspiration (sweating)
  5. Eye movement
  6. Preserved reflexes (coughing)
  7. Movement on painful stimuli
  8. Laryngospasm / Bronchospasm
  9. Tachypnea
  • Through investigations:
  1. beta waves on EEG
  2. Evoked responses
  3. Bispectral index
  • Bispectral index(BIS):

It is the first quantitative EEG index used in clinical practice as a monitor to assess the depth of anesthesia. It consists of a sensor, a digital signal converter, and a monitor. The sensor is placed on the patient’s forehead to pick up the electrical signals from the cerebral cortex and transfer them to the digital signal converter. A BIS score quantifies changes in the electrophysiologic state of the brain during anesthesia.  A score of 45-60 is considered as adequate depth (score of 100 is for fully awake state and O for completely silent brain)

Recurrent TB case – A TB patient previously declared as successfully treated (cured/treatment completed) and who is subsequently found to be microbiologically confirmed TB case is a recurrent TB case. (Previously called relapse.)

Treatment after loss to follow-up – A TB patient previously treated for TB for one month or more and who was declared lost to follow-up in their most recent course of treatment and subsequently found microbiologically confirmed TB cases. (Previously called treatment after default )

questions.text: All the following are quantitative variables except:
questions.solution:
• Variables are classified as
    1. Qualitative/Categorical variable
    2. Quantitative variable

Qualitative subclassified into again three

  • Nominal (denoting names)- eg: gender, blood group
  • Ordinal (having order) eg: APGAR score, TNM staging
  • Binomial (two outcomes) eg: no of failures/successes, dead/alive

Quantitative subclassified into two

  • Continuous variable (having decimals)- Height, weight, temperature scales
  • Discrete variable (only whole numbers)- No. of children, no. of states in a country

questions.text: Age pyramid of India is:

A population pyramid illustrates the age and sex structure of a country's population.  The population is distributed along the horizontal axis, with males shown on the left and females on the right. questions.text: Whose name is associated with the fracture shown below?
questions.solution: There is a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. This is a Colle's fracture. Colle's fractures usually occur when an adult falls on a hyperextended, outstretched hand. There is frequently an associated fracture of the ulnar styloid. Although Colle's fractures are not intra-articular fractures, secondary degenerative arthritis may develop at the wrist joint.

questions.solution:

    • A Population subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test

questions.text: For a 60kg Indian male, minimum daily protein requirement has been calculated to be 40gm ± 10 (SD). RDA of protein would be:
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance (RDA) is the average daily dietary intake level that suffices to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy persons of a specific sex, age, life stage, or physiological condition (such as pregnancy or lactation).

RDA is defined as two standard deviations above the average requirement, assuming that the distribution of nutrient requirements is normal

So RDA is Mean+ 2 SD for all nutrients except for energy

questions.text: After Gastrectomy surgery by the Chief, the CRRI is given chance to suture the skin. The CRRI is suturing by the following technique. This is known as
Which of the following indicator is used for growth monitoring at Anganwadi centre?
questions.solution:
Growth charts are a tool for tracking a child's physical growth and development done as follows

  • Step A: Find the child's age at the bottom of the chart and draw a vertical line on the growth chart (from top to bottom).
  • Step B: Now find the child's weight on the right-hand side of the chart, 30, and draw a horizontal line (from left to right).
  • Step C: Find the spot where these two lines intersect or cross each other.
  • Step D: Find the curve that is closest to this spot and follow it up.
  • If falling in Green zone- well nourished
  • If falling in Yellow zone- moderately malnourished
  • If falling in Red zone- severely malnourished

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office with petechiae and bruising on the face, chest, back, and lower extremities, which her mother noticed early this morning. The mother states that her daughter has been healthy except for a viral upper respiratory illness 2 weeks ago. Laboratory assessment reveals a platelet count of 25,000/microlitre without any splenomegaly. Which of the following statements regarding the likely diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis fits into a presentation of acute-onset ITP.

Points to note:

  • Onset of petechia 2 weeks following a viral illness
  • Platelet count showing thrombocytopenia
  • No splenomegaly.

Since there is no mucosal or life-threatening bleeding, only observation is sufficient. There is no role of platelet transfusions in acute ITP. Also note that hemarthroses are a feature of coagulation disorders, not common in platelet disorders. Platelet disorders more commonly show superficial bleeds like petechiae and epistaxis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child, weighing 7 kg, was admitted to a hospital in view of severe acute malnutrition. The child was evaluated and found to have features of xerophthalmia, with no Vitamin A drops received in the past. What dose and regimen of Vitamin A administration is recommended in this child?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is not a frequent association with severe acute malnutrition and is an important cause of blindness caused by keratomalacia.

  • Vitamin A should therefore be given to all severely malnourished children on day 1 at 50,000 IU, 100,000 IU and 200,000 IU for infants 0-5 month, 6-12 months and children> 1 year of age unless there is definite evidence that a dose has been given in the last month.
  • In presence of xerophthalmia, the same dose should be repeated on the next day and 2 weeks later.
  • Children > 1 year but weighing <8 kg should receive half the age-related dose.
  • In presence of clinical evidence of xerophthalmia the administration of Vitamin A should be considered an emergency as the changes may progress to keratomalacia within hours.
  • In the given question, since the weight of child is less than 8 kg, so half the age-wise dose is needed and total 3 doses are needed in view of xerophthalmia being present, as per OP Ghai 9th Ed.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed to have ocular myasthenia gravis, what is the likelihood of having a positive AChR antibody test?
questions.solution:
• Antibodies to acetylcholine receptor antibodies (anti-AChR) is virtually diagnostic of MG, but negative test does not exclude the disease.
  • Anti-AChR antibodies are detected in the serum of ~ 85% of all myasthenic patients, but only in about 50% of patients with weakness confined to the ocular muscles.
  • 40% of generalised MG patients who are negative for anti-AChR antibody have antibodies to MuSK.
  • MuSK antibodies are rarely present in anti-AChR antibody positive patients or in patients with ocular MG.
  • Patients with MuSK antibody positive MG responds less well to thymectomy than those with AChR antibody.
  • Patients with MuSK antibody positive MG responds less well to anticholinesterase medications than those with AChR antibody
